action.action-desc: Ms. Kuster of New Hampshire (for herself, Mr. Jenkins of West Virginia, Mr. Ryan of Ohio, and Mr. Cooper) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on the Judiciary, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To repeal the amendments made to the Controlled Substances Act by the Ensuring Patient Access and Effective Drug Enforcement Act of 2016.

section.header: Repeal of the Ensuring Patient Access and Effective Drug Enforcement Act of 2016

subsection.header: Registration process under the Controlled Substances Act
subsection.text: Sections 1 and 2 of the Ensuring Patient Access and Effective Drug Enforcement Act of 2016 (Public Law 114–145; 130 Stat. 354) and the amendments made by such sections are repealed.

subparagraph.header: Factors as may be relevant to and consistent with the public health and safety
subparagraph.text: Section 303 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 823) is amended by striking subsection (j).

subparagraph.header: Imminent danger to the public health or safety
subparagraph.text: Section 304(d) of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 824(d)) is amended—

clause.text: by striking (d)(1) The Attorney General and inserting (d) The Attorney General; and

paragraph.header: Opportunity to submit corrective action plan prior to revocation or suspension
paragraph.text: Section 304(c) of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 824(c)) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by striking (c)(1) Before and inserting (c) Before; and

by adding at the end the following: The order to show cause shall contain a statement of the basis thereof and shall call upon the applicant or registrant to appear before the Attorney General at a time and place stated in the order, but in no event less than thirty days after the date of receipt of the order. Proceedings to deny, revoke, or suspend shall be conducted pursuant to this section in accordance with subchapter II of chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code. Such proceedings shall be independent of, and not in lieu of, criminal prosecutions or other proceedings under this title or any other law of the United States..
